newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Phillips starts up Belgian plastics facility.
newsitem.headline: Phillips starts up Belgian plastics facility.

text.p: Phillips Petroleum Co inaugurated a new Ryton PPS (polyphenylene sulfide) compounding facility near the northern port city of Antwerp on Monday to improve its service to European and African customers.

"If markets continue to grow like this, this facility will enable us to maintain our market share and stay the dominant player," Phillips Petroleum engineering plastics manager Werner Lehnert told a news conference.
He said the plant would complement similar compounding facilities in Houston and Borger, Texas, and in Singapore.

Ryton is a heat- and chemical-resistant engineering plastic which can also be moulded to tight tolerances. It is used in electronic components, under-the-hood car parts in which it can replace metal and appliances.
Compounding is combining Ryton PPS with glass fibers or mineral fillers to tailor it to customer needs.
Initial capacity at the Antwerp facility, Phillips' single biggest compounding unit, will be 4,000 tonnes a year of compounded Ryton PPS, but can be raised to about 12,000 tonnes a year if required.
"We expect to double our capacity here in four to five years," Lehnert said.
Benny Mermans, Phillips' Ryton marketing manufacturing manager for Europe and Africa, said the company invested nearly $7 million in the facility. The building is leased.
He said Europe and Africa represented 30 percent of the world market of compounded PPS, currently estimated at around 35,000 a year. Phillips takes up 70 percent of that market share.
